title: Auto-onboard smallholder farmers
description: アフリカの人口の60％は何らかの農業活動に従事していると言われています。零細農家をカルダノに乗せるには、インセンティブが不足しています。

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal problem statement ("60% of Africa's population is engaged in some kind of agricultural activity. Onboarding smallholder farmers to Cardano lacks incentives.") do not match the Solution ("We use satellites to detect field boundaries to identify and onboard farmers, so they can claim financial incentives and link to consumers.").
Ignoring the mismatch of the problem statement and the proposed solution, the proposed solution gives an in-debt breakdown of how it will solve Farm product traceability which really solves a real world problem of traceability of African food / Farm product supply chain.
The proposal presented unverifiable metrics without any references.
The Motivation section of the proposal completely displays a lack of understanding of the food problem in Africa and prioritise cutting down CO2 emissions ahead of availability to feed which is a more pressing than climate change without providing references to Africa's contribution to Green House Gases.
The proposal is very viable for other products especially the African Manufacturing sector or Traceability of medication .
The line "The data frame infrastructure will be able to calculate the environmental impact of all food products in European stores, allowing consumers to make informed food choices, and food suppliers to understand and change their product's specific environmental footprint." clearly shows that this solution is more relatable to developed countries producing lots of Green House Gases and was beaten down to fit in to Africa without proper research on Africa the Green house position of Africa.
I think a proper research is done as regards to this Solution with Africa in mind.
I strongly disagree that this proposal effectively address the challenge .
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal did not present any verifiable experience with links.
The implementation plan seem bloated without a proper breakdown of timelines, milestones and cost breakdown especially considering the requested amount of $200000.
The proposal fund request seem to be too high considering the fund pot is $250000 without considering other proposal funding.
I strongly disagree.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal did not present any information that will help to audit the progress of implementation .
Considering the above, i strongly disagree.

f6_assessments.q0:
General Challenge Setting:
Amazing idea and great insights within this proposal!  It seems that some groundwork has been laid with the already established projects from the consortium. The system is probably very well thought out already. That's why I'm, to better assess the effect on the challenge, missing details on: execution; how this affects the Cardano ecosystem; how the 200k will be spent and also KPIs.
Especially the missing budget breakdown and the sentence "We are looking for additional funds and partners." makes me wonder why Cardano can't be a partner without the $200k from the Catalyst community?
----------

Impact statements in proposal:

1) "End-Consumers can access the public information stored on the blockchain directly and contribute funds downstream."

2) "Events such as deforestation and other land-use changes, which have a great influence on environmental footprint"
----------

Assessment of impact statements:

1) Why will they contribute funds and how, if they can access public information for free?

- not clear how this impacts the Cardano community, also Atala Prism was not mentioned but a dedicated "cascading identities" feature was introduced

2) What about "common" malpractices like use of monoculture, pesticides, deep ploughing and more, that create such and similar events in the first place? Is someone validating those data points and if yes how? 

- questionable: website hummingbird tech makes claims about "regenerative agriculture  data science" and then shows images of monoculture and deep ploughing below! This doesn't fit together and makes me wonder how well the proposers understand the term regenerative agriculture.
----------

Rationale given for score:
Too many open questions for me to correctly assess impact, the effect on challenge respectively. See questions above. Maybe I didn't go deep enough into the other projects - in that case sorry! I really dig the seed of this idea and hope that the proposers will propose more detailed slices of it for the fund7!
f6_assessments.q1:
Feasibility statements:
1) "supply chain actors' participation towards deriving food products' specific environmental impact from their actual supply chain traceability data"

2) "onboard farmers, so they can claim financial incentives and link to consumers."

3) "tracking of transactions of food items along the value chain, (all information) will be linked into the Cardano infrastructure"

4) "Any contribution towards optimizing yields and improving patterns for sustainable fair trade, that is beyond their own capacity, they can directly ask consumers for support."

5) Dispute System: "third actors and verifications schemes (e.g. governmental agencies) can resolve it."

6) "to recover funds and identity given the circumstance of lost credentials. These trusted parties will never have access to the private key of the wallet and are only allowed to intervene by the conditions set by the user of the original wallet."
----------

Assessment of feasibility
1)  What incentive do specific actors have, to be transparent?

2) Financial incentives are mentioned but not how they are generated or where they come from, neither how this will work in a bit more detail. It feels like the whole downstream incentive mechanism could be sliced into at least two proposals: incentives structure for independent/small scale (more easy to enact change) food processors; and; (gamified) incentive structure for consumers; or sth similar. This would make the epic solution much

3) How is it linked? Tracking all information on chain can be expensive. Who will pay for having all this data on the chain? 

4) How will this work? What format will be used? Sounds like a separate proposal in itself

5) What if governmental agency has no capacity or is biased?

6) how can they recover if they don't have any means of accessing any of your private keys? Maybe looking into sth like "Secure multi-party computation" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_multi-party_computation would be helpful to define another separate project that could submit another proposal that is more feasible and auditable.
----------

Rationale given for score:

Many unknowns for feasibility. Recommended to look at one of underlying features and pilot it into a live environment; then tackle the next feature, until all features are integrated.
f6_assessments.q2:
Audibility Statement in proposal:

1) "The infrastructure will enable the automated collection of data about production practices through remote sensing based on geo-space technologies"
----------

Assessment of audibility:
1) Who is validating geo-space data?
Who is setting up & maintaining geo space data oracles or hardware? Will it be only hummingbird? If no how are the oracles funded? If yes how do you ensure data can be trusted by farmers, end consumers and supply chain actors, ie that there wont be (lobbying for) oracle data manipulation? 

2) Who's auditing the Eaternity score system? Also why is the pricing so high?
What small scale farmer can spend 1200€ per product on an Eaternity score? especially if he is taking regenerative agriculture serious and is working with many products in a mixed permaculture?
----------

Rationale given for score:
I couldn't find any KPIs, hence the audibility of this proposal will be almost impossible.

f6_assessments.q1: The proposer have been already worked in similar kind of project their past experience will be really helpful for this proposal and they have provided a detailed plan so, it's very likely this proposal will be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has provided a detailed timeline which will be helpful to audit the progress of proposal but a detailed fund breakdown would have been more helpful to track the progress and success of the proposal

f6_assessments.q0: Massive project and the proposal that attempts to identify a valid problem which I found to be plausible. The solution however, I found wanting and perhaps this is because of the scale of the project. While many positive outcomes were detailed I found them difficult to equate to positive outcome for an individual farmer without some sort of example. Further taking a whole of Africa approach makes for a political and social complex problem that is at a incomprehensible scale. I would like to see this project applied to a smaller entity to prove worth with actual realistic outcomes for small scale farmers   that could then be extrapolated to wider regions. That would allow me to see the value equations for the players involved including the Catalyst community.
f6_assessments.q1: The experience of the team appears sound on some levels of the project although the need to employ developers is noted and remains a little vague. Certainly I can commend the proposer for taking a big picture approach but feel that contains a large degree of risk that the mitigation of such is not discussed in this proposal. The budget is excessive and I would advise that the proposal be scaled back to a practical application that addresses a smaller community that could then be scaled up as milestones are achieved. I found the plan difficult to assess on a practical level as this project is simply too large to measure in terms of achievable metrics in a short timeframe.
f6_assessments.q2: The information provided is extensive but I failed to find  it sufficient to allow for auditability in its present form. I feel there is a very useful project for Catalyst and the Cardano community in there somewhere but at present we have an untested macro solution. The proposal needs to be resubmitted with a think locally  then act globally scale up design. At present given the timeframe we are working with the deliverables simply do not add up.

f6_assessments.q0:
Basically, this proposal is the future. This proposal has the potential of make waves all over the world.  And Africa is the perfect place for resonate in that part of the supply chain.  But, if the proposers really want to have a true impact on Africa (and with Africa, in the hole world) they will have to put a lot of soil in their code.  An intense amount of work on the field carries an initiative of those dimensions.  Because, actual consumers (for conscience reasons) and retailers (for competition reasons) in the cities already are delighted with the idea, the interface, the tecnology, the philosophy, the major and beautiful purpose.  All of it.   And that covers the final links of the supply chain.  But, although if there is an impact at the end an impact at the beginning is inevitable, that could take a lot more time.  And I suposse that you want to save the planet now?

The impact over the front-end of the supply chain is important but without an active intervention on the back-end, the impact tends to weaken.

The proposers will have to make a lot of work with the African farmers.  And not only with them.   With its circumstances (the will of farmer's community are going to be your main ally, as long as you show respect for their wishes: they don't want charity, they want to be an integral part of the process and the final creation):  politicians, burocrats, legal obstacles, farmer's supliers and its own interests, and of course, lady corruption.  But remeber: the future is here and it is now, and not even theycan do something about it.

The information provided by the proposal suggest a wide knowledge of the environmental problematic and an proposal already ahead in the process of its execution.  Partnerships and capital already are on the table.  

However, a proposal without a plan of implementation or a budget clearly outline and broken down into identifiable items, which does not describe the activities to be done in the field is an proposal without a key piece in its engine.    

And the proposal is requesting almost a half of the budget assigned to the challenge, so it's an important thing.

A first step could be a partnership with an organization like WADA (https://wadalliance.org/), which is an active member of the Cardano's community.
f6_assessments.q1:
The information provided by the proposal suggest serious players in the game: partnerships and capital already are on the table.   However, the plan of implementation and the budget don't take in account the reasons exposed in the previous assestment (not even a little bit of work in the field).  So, I consider the successful implementation will be dificult.  

Also, the proposer has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer does not present metrics/KPIs that define the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is very consistent with the main objectives of the challenge, because it seeks to create a blockchain, where producers/farmers can store diverse information about the food production chain. It relates to Africa because, according to the author, around 60% of the local population has some kind of connection with the farmer, so by creating a blockchain network that dialogues with this economy, the author can benefit both the continent and the Cardano ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: The author draws a roadmap based on months. It tells us what will be done in 3, 6 and 12 months. It would be interesting, however, to understand more about how this satellite mapping works mentioned in the first 3 months. It is something very new for most people, if the author had attached some video addressing the subject, we would have a better understanding of this part of the project. The author spends a lot of time explaining how the issue of open or semi-open regime of information coined in the blockchain would be, but he leaves out of the explanation crucial details for the analysis of the proposal. For example, at the beginning we have the knowledge that this is a consortium of companies focused on the food sector, and links through which we can obtain more information about each one of them. However, we do not know who the people involved actually are. Only a few people from these companies would be part of the project, do you agree? We would need to understand who they are, where they come from, what to do and so on. Another thing, unfortunately the author did not include in the details how the funding money would be used. Thus, we have no idea of ​​how the 200k financing he asked for would be distributed, a very high amount.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately the author does not provide us with any information concerning auditability. In other words, we do not have success metrics, which would help the community to monitor the progress of the project. We also don't have a very clear idea of ​​the impact he wants to achieve. Look, we have the motivation, but it's different. Motivating means giving energy to do something, impacting is the result of these actions, it would be necessary for the author to clarify which differences he would like to see on a macro and micro scale. He elaborates very well on the project's needs, but during the reading we have not provided the main impacts of the project, things are said in a somewhat abstract way, we know that the main objective is to protect the work of those who deal with agriculture, but the details would need to go further.
